Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the court grant a stay of deportation for an applicant who overstayed his visa and was convicted of a criminal offense, based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed his visa, was convicted of assault, married after receiving a deportation order, and spouse applied for humanitarian grounds.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for stay of deportation dismissed
Crimes.Court_Ruling: No jurisdiction under s. 18.2 of the Federal Court Act; no serious issue warranting intervention
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Overstayed visa, committed assault, sought relief post-conviction
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on marriage to Canadian citizen
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Exceptional humanitarian and compassionate grounds required under Section 19(1)(c)
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Criminal conviction, timing of marriage, failure to regularize status earlier
Crimes.Applicable_Legislation: Immigration Act, Section 19(1)(c), Federal Court Act s. 18.2
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Jurisdiction of the court to review immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Review_Standard: Tripartite test: serious issue, balance of convenience, irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No finding of bad faith by immigration officer
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Marriage certificate, criminal record, application for humanitarian relief
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Marriage after deportation order, lack of prior compliance
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Individuals with criminal convictions may be inadmissible unless exceptional H&C grounds exist
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of exceptional circumstances outweighing criminality
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential family separation, but outweighed by public interest in enforcement
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant overstayed visa, committed crime, sought to avoid deportation through post-order marriage
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Officer considered humanitarian application but denied due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Timing of marriage relative to deportation order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Court lacks jurisdiction under s. 18.2 if prior decisions conflict
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Humanitarian claim assessed but found insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Immigration officer properly exercised discretion; balance of convenience favors respondent
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Post-deportation-order marriage weakens credibility of humanitarian claim
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds under Immigration Act

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Bodily harm caused, criminal conviction while unlawfully present
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Marriage to Canadian citizen, presence of child
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support conviction and inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal record, immigration documents, family status documentation
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as valid by immigration officer and court
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk of reoffending or non-compliance with immigration laws
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential threat due to criminal history
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canadian federal immigration and criminal law
Crimes.Applicable_Statute: Section related to assault causing bodily harm (Criminal Code), Immigration Act s. 19(1)(c)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code â€“ Assault causing bodily harm
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and Immigration Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Beyond reasonable doubt (criminal), balance of probabilities (immigration)
Crimes.Legal_Procedure: Application for stay of deportation, judicial review
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review under Federal Court Act
Crimes.Authority: Immigration officer has discretionary authority under Immigration Act
Crimes.Decision_Standard: Reasonableness and fairness in administrative decision-making
